author: By Debra Kamin
title: Will There Be Mardi Gras?
description: Yes. And Coachella, too. After canceling many major events over the last two years, organizers are going forward in the first months of 2022, though there may be adjustments.
content: After being walloped in 2020 and 2021, organizers of major late winter and early spring events, from the Super Bowl to the National Cherry Blossom Festival, were hoping 2022 would offer a return to normal. But the rapid-fire spread of the Omicron variant has infected tens of millions of Americans and even more worldwide, and has the organizers of some big events changing plans. Just three weeks before it was scheduled to restart in person in Park City, Utah, the Sundance Film Festival, pivoted to an all-virtual edition, which launched Jan. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cutter
title: Democrats Should Take a Page From Mitch McConnell’s Book
description: The deliberative process that our team followed with Obama’s nominees is outdated. Democrats should move as quickly as possible.
content: With Justice Stephen Breyer’s announcement that he will retire from the Supreme Court this summer, President Biden has a chance to take the landmark step of putting the first Black woman on the court, while shaping the future of jurisprudence. Thanks to President Donald Trump and the former Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell, there is a new set of rules in place for Supreme Court nominations that all but guarantees Democrats will succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Some Baby Formulas Are Out of Stock. Here’s How to Handle the Shortage.
description: Parents are worried, but experts say you can still keep your baby fed and nourished.
content: In addition to other stresses parents are facing as the coronavirus pandemic continues to disrupt work, school and family life, some baby formulas are out of stock in parts of the country, causing caregivers to worry about how they will continue to feed their infants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Harris Seeks Ally in Honduras as She Revisits Central America
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s trip was viewed as more than just showcasing the U.S. presence at the inauguration of Xiomara Castro, the first female head of state in Honduras.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Kamala Harris visited Honduras on Thursday to attend the presidential inauguration of Xiomara Castro, the country’s first female head of state, who the White House hopes will become a crucial ally in addressing the corruption and emigration that have challenged Central America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
title: In Standoff With Putin, Biden Makes Sure European Allies Are With Him
description: In what amounts to a much-needed diplomatic reset, the U.S. is orchestrating the response to Russia’s threatening moves and making sure to include his European allies.
content: LONDON — When President Biden held a video call with European leaders about Ukraine this week, it had all the urgency of a Cold War-era crisis, replete with the specter of Russian tanks and troops menacing Eastern Europe. But Mr. Biden expanded the seats on his war council, adding Poland, Italy and the European Union to the familiar lineup of Britain, France and Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Let Kids Take Their Masks Off After the Omicron Surge
description: There’s a cost to making kids cover their faces indefinitely.
content: Elissa Perkins, the director of infectious disease management in the emergency department of the Boston Medical Center, told me she spent most of 2020 “imploring everybody I could in every forum that I could to mask.” In the beginning, she said, this was to flatten the curve, and later to protect the vulnerable. But masking, she said, “was intended to be a short-term intervention,” and she believes we haven’t talked enough about the drawbacks of mandating it for kids long-term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Mayor’s Crime Plan Is Loathed by Liberals. But It Might Work.
description: To address New York City’s rising gun violence, Eric Adams called on “all of us” to make the streets safer.
content: Earlier this week, Mayor Eric Adams released a 15-page document, “The Blueprint to End Gun Violence,” with the purpose of alleviating a “public health crisis that continues to threaten every corner of the city.” It was work, the introduction maintained, that “will take all of us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Broadway Couple Says ‘I Do’ to Great Applause
description: Bryan Terrell Clark, an actor, and Devario Simmons, a costume designer, had a common bond in challenging upbringings. Their relationship was the opposite.
content: Before the Omicron surge caused dozens of people to drop off the wedding guest list of Bryan Terrell Clark and Devario D. Simmons, it shut down “Thoughts of A Colored Man,” the Broadway show that counted Mr. Clark as a star and Mr. Simmons as costume designer. Mr. Clark hated not having the chance to take a final bow with his castmates. But he did have his final bow as a single man to look forward to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Rosenstrach
title: A Cooks Tour: 3 Picture Books About Famous Foodies
description: Georgia Gilmore, Alice Waters and Julia Child show kids that food has the power to make our worlds bigger, better and more connected.
content: SWEET JUSTICEGeorgia Gilmore and the Montgomery Bus BoycottBy Mara RockliffIllustrated by R. Gregory Christie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yulia Latynina
title: Putin Is Caught in a Trap of His Own Making
description: The Kremlin’s Ukraine gamble has failed.
content: MOSCOW — The question is on everyone’s lips. Will President Vladimir Putin go to war against Ukraine? To judge by Russia’s propaganda machine, where media moguls are predicting a victory “in 48 hours,” the answer is an emphatic yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Jonathan Brown, Influential Historian of Spanish Art, Dies at 82
description: He played a crucial role in reinvigorating a neglected area of Western art history, bringing figures from the past to life.
content: Jonathan Brown, an art historian, curator and teacher who produced magisterial studies of Diego Velázquez, El Greco and other painters of the so-called Golden Age of 16th- and 17th-century Spanish painting, and who went on to do groundbreaking work on Spanish colonial art in Latin America, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Russia Has Enough Troops Near Ukraine for Full Invasion, Pentagon Says
description: Russia has massed more than 100,000 troops at Ukraine’s borders, officials said, publicly confirming what intelligence analysts have described for weeks.
content: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has deployed the troops and military hardware needed to invade all of Ukraine, the Pentagon’s top leaders said on Friday, as senior Defense Department officials warned that the tense standoff was leading the United States, its NATO allies and Russia into uncharted territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadaf Qureshi
title: What He Hadn’t Told Me
description: We met on a dating app, where his profile lacked a few crucial details.
content: At first, he was a fairy tale. Later, an addiction. We met the old-fashioned way — on a Muslim dating app. I had swiped right. Because he had kind eyes, or because a random phrase from his profile resonated with me. Because he understood the difference between “your” and “you’re.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: F.B.I. Secretly Bought Israeli Spyware and Explored Hacking U.S. Phones
description: Israel used the NSO Group’s software as a tool of diplomacy. The F.B.I. wanted it for domestic surveillance. Then everything soured. Here are highlights of a New York Times Magazine investigation.
content: It is widely regarded as the world’s most potent spyware, capable of reliably cracking the encrypted communications of iPhone and Android smartphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Lori Lightfoot Promised to Change Chicago. Crises Keep Piling Up.
description: Ms. Lightfoot has shown herself to be a blunt orator and unflinching negotiator.
content: CHICAGO — Days into a dispute between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and the Chicago Teachers Union, labor leaders outlined what they described as a grand compromise. Students, who had been receiving no instruction after teachers voted to stop reporting to classrooms amid a coronavirus surge, would attend a few days of online school, followed by a full, in-person return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Rifle Used by Kyle Rittenhouse in Kenosha Shootings Will Be Destroyed
description: Mr. Rittenhouse was acquitted of all charges in the fatal shootings of two men and wounding of another during a protest in 2020 that was precipitated by the shooting of a Black man by a police officer.
content: The semiautomatic rifle used by Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager acquitted of criminal charges in the fatal shooting of two men and the wounding of another during a street protest in Kenosha, Wis., in 2020, will be destroyed under an agreement approved by a judge on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Like Many a Lemon
description: Jem Burch makes his second appearance in the New York Times Crossword.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s welcome back Jem Burch, who made his debut in the New York Times Crossword in April, when he was a senior in high school. Now, he is a first-year student at Yale, studying linguistics and (probably) Slavic languages. It’s nice to see that he has continued making puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shruti Swamy
title: The Lives of Black Women, at Home and Abroad
description: Three debut novels — by Kai Harris, Nikki May and Destiny O. Birdsong — follow female protagonists struggling to find their place.
content: WHAT THE FIREFLIES KNEW By Kai Harris 274 pp. Tiny Reparations. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers
title: For Olympic Sponsors, ‘China Is an Exception’
description: Pressure is mounting on companies to condemn the country’s human rights violations, but executives say the Games should not be politicized.
content: At the bottom of the slope where snowboarders will compete in the 2022 Beijing Olympics, an electronic sign cycles through ads for companies like Samsung and Audi. Coca-Cola’s cans are adorned with Olympic rings. Procter & Gamble has opened a beauty salon in the Olympic Village. Visa is the event’s official credit card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Scottish Chicken Soup Is Its Own Kind of Medicine
description: Rich with chicken, leeks and prunes, this cock-a-leekie soup from Melissa Clark is a penicillin of a different order.
content: A rare upside to living in a pandemic has been that, thanks to all the mask-wearing and distancing, I’ve managed to avoid my usual onslaught of winter colds. This has radically altered my chicken soup habits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Fiery North Korean Defector Charged Under New Propaganda Law
description: South Korea banned the spreading of leaflets across the border last year. Park Sang-hak, an outspoken activist who defied the ban, was indicted this week.
content: SEOUL — A North Korean defector has been indicted on charges of breaking a South Korean law that banned the spreading of propaganda leaflets along the inter-Korean border, prosecutors and lawyers said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is a Bonnet the Trendiest Way to Stay Warm This Winter?
description: A reader seeks guidance on shopping for cold-weather hats.
content: That old saw about losing 80 percent of your body heat through your head that your mother would use to scare you into wearing a hat has been debunked by various scientific studies, including one from the University of Manitoba, in a geographic region that knows its cold, but there’s no question that wearing a hat is a good idea in winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Marcelo Claure Leaves Masa Son’s Orbit
description: The exit of SoftBank’s chief operating officer comes as the tech giant faces huge challenges.
content: SoftBank said today that Marcelo Claure was stepping down as C.O.O. The departure of a longtime lieutenant to the investment giant’s chief, Masa Son, comes as the company faces huge challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Kaplan
title: Two Simple Tricks That Help Owls Stay in Their New Homes
description: A study shows that there is a way to successfully transplant burrowing owls to new habitats when developers build over their homes.
content: As far as wild animals go, the western burrowing owl is a tolerant neighbor to humans. When new houses and roads are built next to the tunnels that they call home, these owls put up with the noise and carry on hunting the insects and rodents that they eat. But the owls are increasingly on a collision course with humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: For Them, It Was Love and Baseball
description: Jonathan Cottrell and Erik Braverman met over piña coladas in Mexico and married at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles.
content: Erik Braverman and Jonathan Cottrell’s wedding at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, where Mr. Braverman works as a senior vice president for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was a celebration of love. Also of progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Republicans Relish Biden’s Troubles, Eyeing a Takeover of Congress
description: The president’s woes have delighted Republicans, who have been seeking to rehabilitate themselves in the eyes of voters after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Capitol Hill are using President Biden’s failures to fuel their bid to retake control of Congress, focusing on his collapsing legislative agenda, his unfulfilled promise to “shut down” the coronavirus pandemic and rising voter anxieties over school closures and inflation as they seek a winning message for this year’s elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Mathematician Spends His Sundays
description: Everywhere Steven Strogatz goes in the city, he sees math.
content: Steven Strogatz, a math professor at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., has temporarily moved to the city to serve as a math ambassador, of sorts, at the National Museum of Mathematics, known as MoMath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Let’s Talk Tennis, and Politics
description: This year’s Australian Open was controversial even before it started. How’s it going now?
content: The drama of the Australian Open began early this year, before the first match, with the saga of whether or not the top men’s player, Novak Djokovic, would be allowed to stay and play despite being unvaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Held for Five Days in Jail Over Mistaken Identity, His Lawyer Says
description: Leonardo Silva Oliveira, 26, was arrested last week on a warrant out of Palm Beach County for a man with the same name and similar age who was wanted for probation violation charges.
content: Somewhere, a man named Leonardo Silva Oliveira is on the run from the South Florida law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti
title: The Battle for the World’s Most Powerful Cyberweapon
description: A Times investigation reveals how Israel reaped diplomatic gains around the world from NSO’s Pegasus spyware — a tool America itself purchased but is now trying to ban.
content: In June 2019, three Israeli computer engineers arrived at a New Jersey building used by the F.B.I. They unpacked dozens of computer servers, arranging them on tall racks in an isolated room. As they set up the equipment, the engineers made a series of calls to their bosses in Herzliya, a Tel Aviv suburb, at the headquarters for NSO Group, the world’s most notorious maker of spyware. Then, with their equipment in place, they began testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Peter Robbins, Original Voice of Charlie Brown, Dies at 65
description: Mr. Robbins, who first gave voice to the “Peanuts” character in a 1965 Christmas special, had struggled with mental illness and addiction in recent years.
content: Peter Robbins, whose voice brought the “Peanuts” character Charlie Brown to life on television in the 1960s but who struggled with mental illness and served prison time later in his life, died on Jan. 18 in Oceanside, Calif. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. says $11 billion Nord Stream 2 pipeline will not move forward if Russia invades Ukraine.
description: The pipeline to Germany would expand Russia’s capacity to sell gas to Europe, which is already highly dependent on Russian energy.
content: The United States and Germany are increasing their warnings to Moscow that natural gas will not flow through a major new pipeline from Russia to Germany if Russia invades Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Traveling After Omicron
description: A look at vacationing in 2022.
content: Last summer the travel industry got a meaningful bump as vaccinated sightseers left home — in some cases for the first time in over a year. There was optimism in the industry that the trend would continue through the winter months. Omicron changed that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Chevron has its best quarter since 2014, reflecting an oil industry turnaround.
description: The company recorded a profit of $5.1 billion as global prices rose.
content: Chevron, one of the nation’s largest oil companies, reported a fourth consecutive quarterly profit on Friday as oil and natural gas prices continued to recover from the pandemic slump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Russia dismissed a U.N. Security Council meeting as an American P.R. stunt.
description: U.S. officials see the meeting, scheduled for Monday, as a chance to expose Russia to criticism on a global stage. They expressed confidence that it would go ahead as planned.
content: Russia on Friday denounced a scheduled U.N. Security Council meeting on Ukraine as a “clear P.R. stunt” orchestrated by the United States, and signaled Moscow’s intent to derail it. American officials expressed confidence that the meeting, planned to be broadcast live on Monday, would proceed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: To Get the Most From Social Security, Log On
description: A variety of online tools can guide retirees looking to make the most of this benefit — which many older Americans depend on.
content: Laurence Kotlikoff knows a lot of people who are highly educated about money. But Dr. Kotlikoff, a Boston University economics professor, noticed over the years that many of his academic colleagues were making bad choices about one of their most important retirement benefits: when to claim Social Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Pennsylvania Court Says State’s Mail Voting Law Is Unconstitutional
description: The decision, which could deal a blow to voting access in a critical battleground state, was immediately appealed.
content: A state court in Pennsylvania on Friday struck down the state’s landmark election law as unconstitutional, dealing a temporary blow to voting access in one of the nation’s most critical battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: Be Here Now: How to Exercise Mindfully
description: Bringing meditation into your movement can enrich your workout and help you feel clearheaded afterward.
content: It was a windy summer day in southeastern Tasmania, and Heather Larsen, a professional slackliner, was standing on an inch-wide stretch of nylon suspended between two of the tallest sea cliffs in the Southern Hemisphere. Nearly 1,000 feet below, seals barked and waves pounded the rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Judges Increasingly Demand Climate Analysis in Drilling Decisions
description: A federal judge this week required the government take climate change into account before approving offshore oil drilling leases. That’s becoming more common.
content: WASHINGTON — A judge’s decision this week to invalidate the largest offshore oil and gas lease sale in the nation’s history, on grounds that the government had failed to take climate change into consideration, shows that regulatory decisions that disregard global warming are increasingly vulnerable to legal challenges, analysts said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: We Still Can’t See American Slavery for What It Was
description: Data science is unlocking  insights about the U.S. slave system, but there is a danger in trying to quantify suffering.
content: The historian Marcus Rediker opens “The Slave Ship: A Human History” with a harrowing reconstruction of the journey, for a captive, from shore to ship:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: glaive Flexes the Less Hyper Side of His Pop, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Raveena, the Weather Station, Immanuel Wilkins and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: How Prabal Gurung Plans to Fall in Love This Year
description: Also, Bevy Smith and Marina Rust share where they have hunkered down this winter.
content: After a cautious fall social season, the New York charity circuit went into hiatus in December because of the Omicron surge. Here is how some philanthropists and society figures spent the past month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Alarming Levels of Mercury Are Found in Old Growth Amazon Forest
description: The findings, related to gold mining in Peru, provide new evidence of how people are altering ecosystems in dangerous ways around the world.
content: The protected old-growth forest in the Amazon of southeastern Peru appears pristine: Ancient trees with massive trunks grow alongside young, slender ones, forming a canopy so thick it sometimes feels to scientists like evening during the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Holding on Through Tragedy After Tragedy
description: Despite differing backgrounds and work schedules — and a series of losses early in their relationship — Rachel Seals and Elliott Averett never bailed on one another.
content: When Rachel Seals matched with Elliott Averett on Bumble in October 2016, his profile referred to the rugged “Parks and Recreation” character Ron Swanson as a role model. “I told him it wasn’t very Ron Swanson-esque to be on a dating app,” Ms. Seals recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: A New Generation of Influencers Has Discovered D.I.Y. on a Tiny Budget
description: With enough spray paint, hot glue and successful thrift-store runs, almost any space can look like it belongs on the internet.
content: In the spring of 2020, Emily Shaw was a recent college graduate and, like many pandemic graduates, she was living at home with no job and nothing to do. So she decided to put her degree in interior architecture to use and fix up her parents’ house in New Hampshire, chronicling the process on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Kamau Bell: Bill Cosby Is Key to Understanding America
description: The comic and commentator discusses his new documentary, “We Need to Talk About Cosby,” and what Cosby’s story reveals about the “two runaway forces of oppression in America.”
content: When W. Kamau Bell was growing up, Bill Cosby was the “wallpaper of Black America” and an inspiration, Bell said in a recent interview. Bell’s new documentary, “We Need to Talk About Cosby,” surveys the star’s long career and cultural impact, as well as the accusations of sexual assault that culminated in his conviction, on three counts of aggravated indecent assault, in 2018. Cosby was freed from prison in June 2021 after an appeals court ruled that his due process rights had been violated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Supports Biden’s Supreme Court Strategy
description: Trevor Noah joked that Biden will nominate a Black woman to replace Stephen Breyer “because he cares deeply about representation and winning Georgia.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Where Is Jeffrey Epstein’s Money Going?
description: Settlements, upkeep and lawyers have whittled his $600 million estate to about $185 million. A civil fraud suit in the Virgin Islands could wipe out more.
content: When Jeffrey Epstein died, he left behind an estate with an estimated value of $600 million. There were vast financial holdings, a private jet, and palatial properties including an island hideaway, a grand Manhattan mansion and a 7,600-acre New Mexico ranch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Los Angeles Is Changing. Can a Flagship Theater Keep Up?
description: Navigating the pandemic and a shift in leadership, the Center Theater Group is trying to get back its old audience, and find a new one, while rethinking its mission and programming.
content: LOS ANGELES — For 55 years, the Center Theater Group has showcased theater in a city that has always been known for the movies. Its three stages have championed important new works — “Angels in America,” “Zoot Suit” and “Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992,” to name three of its most acclaimed offerings — while importing big-ticket crowd pleasers from Broadway (coming this spring: “The Lehman Trilogy”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: How Trump Coins Became an Internet Sensation
description: Getting to the bottom of a modern mystery.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Right to Die
description: Dying with dignity raises tricky ethical questions.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Woody Allen’s ‘Rifkin’s Festival’ Is Opening in U.S. Theaters
description: The movie is showing after years of resistance to Allen’s work in the United States following renewed attention to Dylan Farrow’s allegations of sexual abuse.
content: Following renewed scrutiny in recent years over the sexual abuse allegations against Woody Allen brought by his adopted daughter, it was unclear whether Allen’s latest film, “Rifkin’s Festival,” would get a U.S. theatrical release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon want to know what’s for dinner. Is cereal OK with everyone?
content: ACROSTIC — I can’t imagine ever meeting an acrostic that I didn’t love, but it’s always special when the passage is by a favorite writer, which is the case today. In the 1980s, I read everything by Laurie Colwin that I could find at Barnes & Noble and in Gourmet magazine; I thought her writing was hilarious, and I’m surprised and saddened to learn that she died young, in 1992.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: The Man at the Center of Arizona’s Primary
description: Spoiler alert: It’s Donald Trump.
content: Senator Kyrsten Sinema has received so much attention recently that you might have forgotten that she’s not the Arizona Democrat up for re-election in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Is Canada the Soccer Rival the U.S. Needs?
description: Young talent has Canada on the brink of its first World Cup berth since 1986. Big ambitions could keep it on top for years to come, and challenge its neighbors to keep pace.
content: Rory Smith subs off this week for James Wagner, who will be reporting on the United States men’s national team around its World Cup qualifying match at Canada on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: It’s Time to End Race-Based Affirmative Action
description: Socioeconomic class is a better justification for it.
content: Back in 2009, I and the sociologist Dalton Conley debated affirmative action with N.A.A.C.P. chairman Julian Bond and Columbia University president Lee Bollinger. In my closing statement I suggested a scenario in which I had a daughter who got into nearly every college she applied to while her similarly credentialed white friends got into schools only here or there. If that happened, I said, the reason, “given the fact that she will not have grown up under anything you could call disadvantage,” would be that:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Joe Exotic Is Resentenced to 21 Years for ‘Tiger King’ Murder-for-Hire Plot
description: Last year, a federal appeals court vacated the initial sentence for the plot, which was featured in the Netflix series “Tiger King.” Petitions for pardons from two presidents have also failed.
content: Joe Exotic, the former Oklahoma zoo owner who was the central figure in the 2020 Netflix documentary series “Tiger King,” was resentenced to 21 years in prison on Friday for the failed murder-for-hire plot targeting Carole Baskin, a self-proclaimed animal-rights activist who had criticized his zoo’s treatment of animals, his lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Michael Avenatti, Stormy Daniels and a Courtroom Time Capsule From 2018
description: In what may be the last chapter in their unlikely story, Mr. Avenatti cross-examined Ms. Daniels for several hours during his trial on Friday.
content: In the hallowed halls of Manhattan’s two federal courthouses, where some of the nation’s most prominent and historic trials have been held, defense lawyers and prosecutors regularly deliver soaring oratory and witnesses testify with deep emotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Is Leveraging the Pandemic Into Its Own Peace Corps
description: Sweetening federal stimulus and AmeriCorps funds with state and local money, the state is cranking out tens of thousands of Youth Service jobs.
content: California’s brand doesn’t emphasize connection. Single-family homes, single-occupant vehicles — we’re supposedly all rugged individuals in the Golden State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Met Opera Never Missed a Curtain. It Hopes Audiences Rebound.
description: Positive tests at the company are falling as the Met prepares to take a long-planned midwinter break. It hopes cases will be down, and audiences up, when it returns.
content: On Saturday evening, if all goes as planned, the Metropolitan Opera will celebrate a milestone: reaching a long-planned midwinter break without having had to cancel a single performance, even as the pandemic created havoc backstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Police Investigation Could Give Boris Johnson a Lifeline in Party Scandal
description: A request by the police that a senior civil servant investigating parties in Downing Street during the lockdown withhold details from her report could give the British prime minister time to regroup.
content: LONDON — Just a week ago, Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s political survival looked very much in doubt, his party in revolt and the public angered over disclosures about parties at Downing Street that violated lockdown rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Honorée Fanonne Jeffers
title: Toni Morrison’s Only Short Story Addresses Race by Avoiding Race
description: “Recitatif,” originally published in 1983 and now available in book form, features a Black girl and a white girl, but Morrison never identifies which is which.
content: RECITATIFA StoryBy Toni Morrison
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Mourners Remember N.Y.P.D. Officer Killed in Shooting: ‘He Was Joy’
description: Detective Jason Rivera, 22, is among the youngest police officers killed in the line of duty in New York City.
content: A sea of blue stretched down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Friday, as thousands of police officers gathered at St. Patrick’s Cathedral to bid farewell to Detective Jason Rivera a week after he was killed responding to a domestic disturbance call in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Citing Pandemic, This Year’s Obie Awards Will Include Streaming Theater
description: For the first time, digital, audio and other virtual productions will be considered for the honors, for Off and Off Off Broadway works.
content: The Obie Awards, an annual ceremony honoring theater work performed Off and Off Off Broadway, this year for the first time will consider digital, audio and other virtual productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Sophie Kasakove
title: Pittsburgh Bridge Collapses Hours Before Biden Infrastructure Visit
description: At least 10 people sustained non-life-threatening injuries, officials said. According to an analysis, addressing the structural issues of Pittsburgh’s nearly 450 bridges would cost $458 million.
content: PITTSBURGH — In the City of Bridges, it was not a standout. The bridge, four lanes of Forbes Avenue raised on a steel frame over a picturesque wooded ravine, carried traffic to and from the neighborhoods on the city’s East End. It was around 50 years old and, according to inspectors, in poor condition, but even by these measures was not particularly exceptional in Pittsburgh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Rookies Ride the Bench, Right? Not on the Nets.
description: The Nets, in a move unusual for a championship contender, have turned to their rookies as starters and key contributors — and not just when there were no other options.
content: When a veteran on the Nets asks Day’Ron Sharpe to do something, most of the time he has to say yes. That might mean making a plate of food for James Harden after a game or getting doughnuts beforehand. Other times, he has to turn the showers on in the locker room or carry the veterans’ bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: The Way We Talk About Climate Change Matters, Bill Nye Says
description: In Monday’s puzzle, “Nye” was the answer to the clue “Bill known as the ‘Science Guy.’”
content: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Diverse Is Your School?
description: Would you characterize your school as being diverse in terms of the racial and socioeconomic makeup of the student body?
content: Describe your school: Is it public or private? How do students get to attend your school? Is it based on geographic area? A test, an audition or high grades? What is the makeup of the student body in terms of race, class, gender, sexuality or religion?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Fish Sauce Is Good for Just About Everything
description: Put it in pasta, stews or this thick, creamy coconut curry from Vietnam.
content: If you have some very fresh anchovies, a heap of salt and a roomy barrel to ferment it all in, you technically have everything you need to make fish sauce. But it takes skill to get to a delicious, uncut first press, a glowy amber ripple of salt, so mellow you can taste it neat, so lavish with umami you feel a warm rush to the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: A Palpably Seductive Search for a Grimoire of Sex Magic
description: In Sara Gran’s occult thriller, “The Book of the Most Precious Substance,” a rare-book dealer falls under the spell of a powerful 17th-century manuscript.
content: In Sara Gran’s sensational occult thriller, THE BOOK OF THE MOST PRECIOUS SUBSTANCE (Dreamland Books, 319 pp., paper, $18.95), the rare-book dealer Lily Albrecht is swept into a hunt for a copy of “the most precise and most effective grimoire of sex magic ever written.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Crypto Became the New Subprime
description: Once again, risky financial products are being sold to the vulnerable.
content: If the stock market isn’t the economy — which it isn’t — then cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin really, really aren’t the economy. Still, crypto has become a pretty big asset class (and yielded huge capital gains to many buyers); by last fall the combined market value of cryptocurrencies had reached almost $3 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor J. Blue, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Safiullah Padshah
title: On Patrol: 12 Days With a Taliban Police Unit in Kabul
description: Tasked with guarding a Shiite shrine, a police unit offers a telling snapshot of the Taliban’s rank-and-file fighters and the challenges Afghanistan’s rulers face in governing a diverse nation.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A young Taliban fighter with a pair of handcuffs dangling from his finger warily watched the stream of approaching cars as he stood in front of a set of steel barricades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Why Can’t We Make Women’s Equality the Law of the Land?
description: Alas, the Constitution doesn’t always mean what it says.
content: Even if you are a political junkie, there’s a good chance you didn’t realize that the United States Constitution grew 58 words longer this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Consumer spending fell in December as Omicron spread.
description: Overall spending fell for the first time since February as the virus and supply chain issues impacted purchases.
content: Consumers pulled back their spending in December, as spiraling coronavirus caseloads kept many Americans at home late in the holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Charlie Savage
title: As Breyer Pondered Retirement, Biden Bet on a Hands-Off Strategy
description: The president believed pressuring the court’s oldest justice to retire might backfire. A chorus of liberals took a different approach.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden had hoped that Justice Stephen G. Breyer would retire soon. But as he and his advisers waited for the most senior member of the Supreme Court’s liberal wing to make up his mind, the president had made it clear: No one was to do anything to pressure him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: When It’s Too Good to Be True
description: “He seemed to adore me, almost instantly.”
content: They met on a dating app during the pandemic. He showered her with compliments and attention. She began to crave his adoration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal and Daniil Medvedev Will Meet in Australian Open Final
description: Nadal defeated Matteo Berrettini and will play for a record 21st career Grand Slam men’s singles title against Medvedev, who beat Stefanos Tsitsipas in four, sometimes testy, sets.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Once again, the last defense against No. 21 will be Daniil Medvedev.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild’ Review: A Franchise Thaws
description: The latest installment in this animated film series replaces nearly all of its celebrity voice performers with close proxies.
content: Upon beginning “The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild,” the sixth feature in the animation franchise that grows woollier by the movie, you sense something amiss. Perhaps it’s the dinosaur paradise serenely preserved beneath alpine glaciers? Can’t be: That particular anachronism has been canon for several “Ice Age” installments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan M. Katz
title: Why Would a Marine Call Himself a ‘Racketeer for Capitalism’?
description: The life of Smedley Butler shows us that we can’t fix American democracy without reckoning with its military interventions.
content: Recently, several troubling stories have appeared on the front page of The Times. One was about the release of video from America’s last, pointless drone strike in Afghanistan before the American troops withdrew — a strike which killed only civilians, seven of whom were children. The article was co-written by Azmat Khan, an investigative journalist who has revealed “a pattern of impunity” in America’s air wars and the deaths of thousands of foreign noncombatants. Other stories concerned the demise of the voting rights bill in the Senate and Donald Trump’s attempt to stonewall the Jan. 6 committee — each a further reminder of the rising threat to U.S. democracy posed by an increasingly authoritarian right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Committee Subpoenas Fake Trump Electors
description: The panel demanded information from 14 people who were part of bogus slates of electors for President Donald J. Trump, digging deeper into an aspect of his efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol attack issued 14 subpoenas on Friday to people who falsely claimed to be electors for President Donald J. Trump in the 2020 election in states that were actually won by Joseph R. Biden Jr., digging deeper into Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Family of Slain ‘Rust’ Cinematographer Weighs Wrongful-Death Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for the family of Halyna Hutchins filed a petition in New Mexico to appoint a representative who will consider whether to file a suit.
content: Lawyers for the family of Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer fatally shot by Alec Baldwin on the set of the movie “Rust” last year, filed a petition this week to appoint a representative for Hutchins’s estate who will consider whether to file a wrongful-death lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Chita Rivera’s Book Will Introduce Fans to the Real Her
description: The Broadway star is writing a memoir with the help of a journalist who encouraged her to share what she’s really like, alter ego and all.
content: Over the last seven decades, the Broadway star Chita Rivera has taken on and defined some of American musical theater’s most iconic roles: Anita in “West Side Story,” Rose in “Bye Bye Birdie,” Velma Kelly in “Chicago.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: What May Be in Store as the Fed Cuts Back on the Easy Money
description: People all over the country — indeed, much of the planet — are depending on the central bank to stave off runaway inflation and keep the economy growing. Prepare for trouble, our columnist says.
content: The world has been awash in trillions of dollars in easy money since early in 2020. Now, some of that money is going away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Players Wear Their Hearts Under Their Uniforms
description: Bound by strict uniform rules, players like Odell Beckham Jr. and Deebo Samuel are honoring peers with customized T-shirts worn in pregame warm-ups and underneath their jerseys.
content: When Odell Beckham Jr. returned in September for his first game with the Cleveland Browns since tearing his anterior cruciate ligament nearly a year ago, he had options for his warm-up gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Philip Glass and the Bangles, Mashed at the Symphony
description: Anthony Roth Costanzo and Justin Vivian Bond brought their gleeful opera-cabaret show “Only an Octave Apart” to the New York Philharmonic.
content: It’s not like the New York Philharmonic hasn’t been queer before. I can’t have been the only boy for whom Jessye Norman’s hair, when she sang Brünnhilde’s Immolation Scene with the orchestra on national television in 1995, was a turning point. The ensemble backed Mariah Carey in Central Park, and Elaine Stritch for Sondheim’s 80th. It once paired Lou Harrison and Bruckner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon, Sameer Yasir and Jason Gutierrez
title: A South Korean naval unit quarantines in Oman after a Covid outbreak on their ship.
description: All 304 crew members aboard a South Korean Navy destroyer dispatched to the Gulf of Aden are quarantining in Oman after 27 of them tested positive for Covid-19, the South Korean military said on Friday.
content: All 304 crew members aboard a South Korean Navy destroyer dispatched to the Gulf of Aden are quarantining in Oman after 27 of them tested positive for Covid-19, the South Korean military said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: A Change of Address
description: This isn’t goodbye.
content: Welcome. The newsletter you’re reading began life as “At Home” in the spring of 2020, with the goal of helping Times readers lead full and cultured lives amid the coronavirus pandemic. In the spring of 2021, optimistic about the ways the vaccine was permitting us to leave our nests, we renamed the newsletter “At Home and Away.” Our lives were opening up, we weren’t always in our houses anymore, but we were still figuring out how to live well while staying safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: And Just Like That, a Generational Shift at Quarterback
description: The evolution at the N.F.L.’s most important position has been clear even with familiar names frequently making deep playoff runs. Today’s emerging stars are taking on more of their team’s offensive load.
content: In these chaotic times, there is great comfort in the familiar, and the most familiar scene in the last four N.F.L. postseasons has been an A.F.C. championship game staged at Arrowhead Stadium, home of quarterback Patrick Mahomes and the Kansas City Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: If G.D.P. Is Up, Why Do VotersFeel So Down?
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 28, 2022.
content: “It’s kind of hard to be cheerful when there’s still a pandemic raging.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Let the Lord Sort Them’ and ‘The Five Wounds’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: LET THE LORD SORT THEM: The Rise and Fall of the Death Penalty, by Maurice Chammah. (Crown, 368 pp., $18.) This thoroughly reported account charts evolving attitudes toward the death penalty in America and covers the people and legal cases that have slowly brought it to near extinction. “Chammah is here to remind us that in our lifetimes a sea change has happened,” our reviewer, Anand Giridharadas, commented. “It’s not over yet. But it’s a triumph all the same.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russia mulls a response to the U.S.
content: After the U.S. and NATO presented a written response to Russia’s demands regarding Ukraine, the Kremlin warned that there was “not much cause for optimism.” As fears of a Russian attack on Ukraine grow by the day, Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, is taking his time to study the response, his spokesman, Dmitri Peskov, said. “We won’t rush to any conclusions,” he added.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A Marker Honoring Jackie Robinson Was Defaced. M.L.B. Helped Replace It.
description: A series of incidents in Georgia appeared to be targeting markers dedicated to Black Americans. “This should not be happening,” said Robinson’s cousin.
content: In the countryside of southwestern Georgia, roughly two miles north of the Florida border, in a small clearing of trees alongside Route 154, a brick chimney stands alone. An accompanying historical marker notes that the house that once stood there burned down in 1996. It’s all that remains of the place where one of the most important figures in American history was born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‘The Exiles’ and ‘Nanny’ Win Top Prizes at Sundance
description: A documentary revisiting dissidents from the Tiananmen Square massacre and a horror film about an undocumented domestic worker took the U.S. Grand Jury prizes at the festival.
content: The horror/drama “Nanny” from the first-time feature filmmaker Nikyatu Jusu nabbed the U.S. Grand Jury prize at this year’s Sundance Film Festival, which was primarily virtual for the second year in a row. The film about a Senegalese nanny working for a privileged family in New York City generated strong reviews and is still looking for distribution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: In the Bronx, a Push to Save Cass Gilbert’s Train Stations
description: Two of the stations designed by the famed architect more than 100 years ago for the old ‘Consolidated’ railroad have a chance to be transformed for new uses.
content: The majestically moldering Bronx stations of the old New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad are, in the words of one architectural historian, like a broken string of pearls. Some have been lost, while “others are being slowly crushed by the boot of time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘His Pictures Rather Put Me Off Meat’: Animal Experts on Francis Bacon
description: A new exhibition at London’s Royal Academy highlights Francis Bacon’s paintings of animals. We showed them to some specialists in their subject matter.
content: LONDON — The painter Francis Bacon was never “particularly fond of animals,” recalled Michael Peppiatt, one of his biographers, in a recent telephone interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a grim western teeming with bloodthirsty outlaws, humans fighting an alien invasion and more.
content: So many action films are massive freak-out affairs with big explosions and even bigger body counts. But every so often I crave modesty, and the writer-director David Beton’s “Confession” perfectly fits the bill. It takes place in a single location, a Massachusetts church, where Victor Strong (Stephen Moyer), a mysterious gunman with a bullet wound in his abdomen, takes a priest hostage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marwan Safar Jalani
title: We Syrians Are Not Surprised by This Betrayal
description: International bodies and nations appear to have either forgiven, forgotten or chosen to ignore the reasons Syria was cast out from their community.
content: Less than 10 years ago, the United Arab Emirates’ foreign minister, Abdullah bin Zayed, spoke up against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria for massacring civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: The world surpasses 10 billion vaccine doses administered, but gaps persist in who gets the shots.
description: Some nations can now envision a near future in which their people coexist with the virus but aren’t confined by it.
content: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rolled up his sleeve in December 2020 to receive a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine, kicking off one of the world’s first mass rollouts of Covid shots, he declared that it marked “the beginning of the end” of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Moses Storm and the Case for Pretentious Modern Stand-up
description: In his new special, the comic claims he has no agenda, but his jokes and stories about poverty cohere into trenchant commentary. Why are themes out of fashion?
content: Surely you’ve heard the grumbles, the sighs and the outright complaints about self-serious comedians making points instead of punch lines, pandering for applause, creating specials that are more like solo theater shows or, the unkindest cut of all, TED Talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: No, athletes are not dying from Covid-19 vaccines.
description: Claims about professional athletes dying after getting vaccinated have been a recurring conspiracy theory since the shots were introduced.
content: The conspiracy theory that athletes are collapsing or dying after receiving a Covid-19 vaccine resurfaced this week after two prominent voices advanced the idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Shadow of a Bribery Investigation
description: Philip Banks III, now the deputy mayor for public safety, was ensnared in a federal corruption investigation when he was a high-ranking police official.
content: Today we’ll look at Philip Banks III, the top criminal justice official at City Hall — seven years after he was caught up in a federal corruption investigation. We’ll also bid farewell to Yolanda Vega, the personality who launched thousands of televised New York Lottery drawings. She’s retiring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How to Draw a Feeling’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how an illustrator created a visual representation of the word “languishing.” Then, they will illustrate emotions they have felt during the pandemic.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Company Bus Ride Set Their Romance in Motion
description: Stephanie Quintero and Eric Wall found instant attraction when they met while en route to a work conference, but took months to formalize a relationship.
content: Stephanie Ann Quintero and Eric Michael Wall did not know each other when they walked out of a Dallas hotel along with 14 colleagues one morning in December 2018. Both employees of the accounting firm Deloitte — she in its Boston office, he out of Detroit — boarded a bus bound for a conference at nearby Deloitte University, the company’s leadership center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: A Few Simple Tricks Yield the Most Tender Pancakes
description: Genevieve Ko whips ricotta into the batter and skips the stiff egg whites for a recipe that’s as effortless as it is comforting.
content: In my Northeastern life, pancakes are for frigid winter mornings, the snow stacking on pine trees outside, my windows fogging from coffee steam. Hot off the griddle, they’re warming against the chill. During the same season in Los Angeles, my hometown, the skies are atypically clear so the sun feels close and soft. Eating a pile of pancakes outside under that glow is as magical as the scent of orange blossoms in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Avenatti Cross-Examines Stormy Daniels, Focusing on the Paranormal
description: Michael Avenatti and his former client, who has accused him of stealing from her, met for a dramatic showdown in court.
content: Early in Michael Avenatti’s cross-examination of his former client Stormy Daniels on Friday, he asked whether, a few years earlier, a “dark entity” had entered her home through a “portal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: New York’s Recovery Took 2 Steps Forward. Omicron Sent It One Step Back.
description: The economic disruptions of the latest Covid wave have hurt blue-collar workers the most, even as Wall Street profits, rents and home sales are soaring.
content: As the pandemic stretches into a third year, the Omicron variant has added another speed bump in New York City’s road back to normalcy, injecting fresh uncertainty into the economic outlook and threatening to worsen the city’s already lopsided recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: The U.K. police ask that some details be omitted from a report on Downing Street parties during a lockdown.
description: LONDON — The British police said on Friday that they had asked for critical details to be withheld from an eagerly awaited government investigation of parties at 10 Downing Street during England’s coronavirus lockdowns, giving Prime Minister Boris Johnson some political breathing space but provoking an outcry from critics.
content: LONDON — The British police said on Friday that they had asked for critical details to be withheld from an eagerly awaited government investigation of parties at 10 Downing Street during England’s coronavirus lockdowns, giving Prime Minister Boris Johnson some political breathing space but provoking an outcry from critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Another Resale at 220 Central Park South Lands in the Record Book
description: The $188 million resale of a duplex is the second-highest price paid for a home in New York City, and leads a busy month for residential sales.
content: The country’s most expensive residential building, 220 Central Park South in Manhattan, once again proved an extraordinary investment for its wealthy buyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Picks Up Another Win and Turns Focus to Canada
description: A victory over El Salvador moved the Americans another step closer to a place in this year’s World Cup in Qatar.
content: The goal celebration, it turned out, provided the match’s final moment of drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
title: Record Payout Awarded to Sexual Abuse Victims in India
description: The case, involving rapes at a shelter for homeless girls, signals a partial reckoning with the government’s responsibility in an epidemic of sexual violence.
content: NEW DELHI — Survivors of a particularly grim corner of India’s welfare system have been awarded thousands of dollars in compensation, a national human rights body announced this week. More than four dozen former residents of a homeless shelter for girls in north India endured horrific conditions; many were sexually assaulted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
title: White House Warnings Over Russia Strain Ukraine-U.S. Partnership
description: While Ukraine’s president complained about “acute and burning” warnings from Washington, the Pentagon issued a dire new appraisal asserting Russia has amassed enough troops to invade his entire country.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian officials sharply criticized the Biden administration Friday for its ominous warnings of an imminent Russian attack, saying they had needlessly spread alarm, even as a new Pentagon assessment said Russia was now positioned to go beyond a limited incursion and invade all of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Neil Young Says ‘No More’ to Spotify
description: Without real streaming alternatives around, a musician’s move to shame Spotify is doomed to failure.
content: It’s no surprise to me that the singer-songwriter Neil Young followed through on his threat to pull his music from Spotify in protest of the Covid misinformation spouted by that streaming service’s brightest star, Joe Rogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: At City Ballet, Giving Voice to the Body, With Sneakers
description: Justin Peck’s “Partita,” set to Caroline Shaw’s Pulitzer-Prize winning composition, opened New York City Ballet’s winter season at Lincoln Center.
content: At the start of Caroline Shaw’s “Partita for 8 Voices,” fragments of sentences bounce in the air like musical notes. “To the side.” “And around.” And later: “The detail of the pattern is movement.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Local Celebrities
description: What notable figures live in your community?
content: Yolanda Vega, the face of the New York Lottery’s on-air drawings for over three decades, known for her vocal flair and playful personality, announced this week that she is retiring. Although she is known to most New Yorkers, her celebrity does not necessarily stretch beyond the state.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Afro-Atlantic Histories to GameStop
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: NADINE IJEWERE: Our Own Selves, by Nadine Ijewere. (Prestel, $55.) The debut monograph by the first Black woman to shoot a Vogue cover reflects the photographer’s roots in Nigeria, Jamaica and South East London.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Imani Perry Talks About ‘South to America’
description: Perry discusses her new book, and Oliver Roeder talks about “Seven Games.”
content: Imani Perry’s new book, “South to America,” joins a tradition of books that travel the South to find keys to the United States: its foundations, its changes and its tensions. Perry, who was born in Alabama, approaches the task from a variety of angles, and discusses some of them on this week’s podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Mona El-Naggar
title: U.S. Blocks $130 Million in Aid for Egypt Over Rights Abuses
description: The Middle Eastern ally continues to buy billions of dollars worth of military equipment from the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — Citing human rights concerns, the United States will not give Egypt $130 million in annual security assistance, officials said on Friday, even as the Biden administration continues to approve billions of dollars in military sales to the Middle Eastern ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: France’s economy bounces back, while Germany’s falters under the strain of Omicron.
description: The European Union’s two largest economies diverged in the final quarter of 2021.
content: France assumed Germany’s traditional role as the driving economic force in Europe after a strong finish to last year, while the German economy contracted in the final three months as it grappled with a resurgence of the coronavirus, official data showed Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Reawakening the Antichrist (and Other Lost Opera Gems)
description: It can be challenging to revive forgotten works like “Antikrist.” But the absence of entrenched traditions can be liberating.
content: BERLIN — The Whore of Babylon, in a grotesque fat suit, belts out a hymn to hedonism midway through the Deutsche Oper’s new production of “Antikrist” here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Are We in Another Housing Bubble?
description: Or, what’s the matter with Dallas?
content: Do you remember the housing bubble? OK, if you’re 35 or younger, probably not — you were a teenager at the most when the bubble burst. But it was a huge deal at the time, and a very strange one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: More Companies Consider Helping Workers Pay Student Loans
description: Employers see the aid as part of a bid to attract workers, especially as the federal pause on student loan payments ends on May 1.
content: As employers seek to hire and keep workers in a challenging job market, more are weighing offering help with student debt repayments as a job benefit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Separatists Kill 10 Pakistani Soldiers in Attack on Outpost
description: The assault was one of the deadliest on Pakistani security forces in recent years and comes at a time of heightened unrest.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The assault on a military post in a remote southwestern district lasted for several hours. Dozens of attackers, belonging to a Baluch separatist group, heavily armed with rocket launchers and sophisticated weapons, outnumbered the Pakistani soldiers. A heavy gunfight killed 10 Pakistani soldiers and one attacker, and the rest managed to escape, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks rally, erasing losses from a turbulent week.
description: The S&P 500 rose 2.4 percent, its biggest one-day jump since June 2020. But some analysts cautioned against reading too much into a single day’s bounce.
content: Wall Street finally found a foothold on Friday, rebounding from days of back-to-back declines with its biggest gain in 18 months as investors grabbed on to glimmers of good news: a strong earnings report from Apple and data on wage growth that came in lower than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Molly Young Is Thinking About Buying a Wheelbarrow
description: In an interview, the Times book critic discusses how she picks what to recommend and describes her reading life at home.
content: As a New York Times book critic, Molly Young often reads three to six books at a time. Under that workload, she says, she likes to spend two hours with one book, then change to another. For her, the practice is sort of like moving from a hot steam to a cold bath. “It resets your circulation,” she said. “I like to shock myself between vastly different books.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson

description: Tens of thousands of overseas Tongans, intimately tied to their homeland, are contending with the pandemic, snarled supply chains and limited communications.

title: What Do Dancers Bring to a Halftime Show? They Complete the Picture.
description: Some dancers recoiled at the prospect of volunteering their services at this year’s Super Bowl halftime show: “You can’t make a living off of exposure.”
content: A Super Bowl halftime show can be gaudy in the most ordinary way, bringing to mind a line from an essay by the choreographer Merce Cunningham: “The music doesn’t have to work itself to death to underline the dance, or the dance create havoc in trying to be as flashy as the music.”

title: Inflation Continued to Run Hot and Consumer Spending Fell in December
description: Prices are rising rapidly, wages are growing and consumers are glum as a fraught economic moment poses big challenges for policymakers.
content: Inflation came in strong and wage growth remained elevated at the end of 2021. At the same time, consumer spending fell in December as spiraling coronavirus caseloads kept many Americans at home and persistent supply chain bottlenecks disrupted holiday shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Watch the Throne: How Joel Coen Came to Make ‘The Tragedy of Macbeth’

content: You make enough movies about people chasing after things — outlaws, money, a kidnapped baby — and eventually someone comes chasing after you. In Joel Coen’s case, his pursuer was William Shakespeare.

title: Carol Speed, Vixen of the Blaxploitation Era, Dies at 76

title: A Sundance With Brains and Guts, Disemboweled and Otherwise

content: When a character took a severed human leg out of a fridge in the horror movie “Fresh,” I laughed then hit pause. I had that luxury because, like everyone else this year, I didn’t have to fly to Utah for the Sundance Film Festival but attended this impressively sanguineous edition at home. So I just fast-forwarded to the leg chopper’s grisly comeuppance. As to the movie, it will do fine without my love: It’s already racked up positive reviews and will be released on Hulu, which is owned by Disney because, well, sometimes dreams really do come true.

content: HASAKA, Syria — A U.S.-backed militia in Syria delivered a surrender-or-die ultimatum on Friday to dozens of Islamic State fighters holding out in a prison a week after they attacked it, saying they would face an all-out military assault if they did not give themselves up.

content: This past December, I met the abstract artist Rochelle Feinstein at her studio — a 900-square-foot space in an industrial office building in Queens, N.Y. — to discuss her upcoming exhibition, “You Again,” a survey of her work that will be displayed simultaneously in six independent galleries in Paris, Zurich, New York, Miami and Los Angeles, beginning this month at Bridget Donahue and Candice Madey in Manhattan. What interests her is, “How can I enter that cultural condition and how can I enter it right now?”

author: By Peter Coy
title: How to Disseminate Science Quickly
description: What’s the best way to release timely research without letting bad information get out?
content: Peer review is both the greatest strength and the greatest weakness of the scientific research system. It filters out bad work and makes good work better. But it can also slow down the dispersal of new ideas, which is a big problem when it comes to tackling fast-changing challenges like the Covid-19 pandemic. And, of course, peer review can fail. Retraction Watch, a website, maintains a list of more than 100 Covid-19 research papers that were peer reviewed, published and then had to be retracted.
